label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, May 20, 1945
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a scheme to join him in Hawaii and telling him of a party she attended, amongst other social activities.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a scheme to join him in Hawaii and telling him of a party she attended, amongst other social activities.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Washington
May 20 1945
Dear Sidney,
I am down here working on my case
and have been here visiting Jim and Joe for a week. To date
nothing has happened to make me believe I shall be allowed
to break the old Navy rule. Its stands like this. The Red
Cross is presenting a letter to the Navy stating that I have
been requested by the Pacific Commissioner to go to Hawaii
to do a specific Job. The matter will then be taken up by
highest Navy channels and a ruling will be made officially
on it one way or the other. I will therefor know in a day or
two. The other thing suggested to me was to have you transferred
to Washington. I said I did not believe you would like this
- and I would rather that order were not issued. Am I right?
I was afraid you might hate to spend a summer in Washington
even tho' we would be together. I am afraid you would have
a dull paper Job here that would not be as interesting as
Pearl Harbor. I feel that id I am officially turned down on
going out there maybe the next best thing if you wanted to
do it, would be to get out of the navy altogether,then we
could both go back to Hawaii as civilians. Please write and
let me know what you would like to do because while all this
is cooking I can make a move for you in one direction or another.
They seem to find it far easier to order you about than to
break navy rules for me, consequently I want to know what
[End Page 1]
2
you would like to do yourself. 
I am going back to New York to-morrow and will be down again
maybe next week to drive my station wagon north for the kids
to use this summer. I have n't got the gas coupons or license
plates yet but theynare under way.
I have had a killing visit here as I have hardly seen my
host and hostess. They have been either out or away most of
theweek. I went to a party last n[i]ght given by Grace Eustice.
A dance in her house,and I danced my arches flat,and my feet 
hurt to-day. I stayed up till nearly 4 A.M. and am dead beat
to-day. The usual old faces were there, Baskerville, Grosver, 
George Carey, Gee Marvel, and dozens of others. It was fun to
dance again,and the champagne was very fine.
Jo and I had lunch together at Chevey Chase and the old place
looked the same only if anything less attractive people.
Mr Newbold had me lunch with him at the Eve Star office to
tell some of my experiences to his buddies. I am really tired
of describing it all or even parts, but so often one cant
refuse. Its too bad I am not allowed to publish it. It would  
be a moneymaker. Its too late for war stories now I am told,
so when the interest again is roused five years from now
maybe I can do somthing about it. David Selznick said the other
day he was using no more war stories for 5 years.
Tom Eastman took me to the theatre the other night and it was
amusing seeing him again. He is a farmer in Maryland, never
leaves the tractor and plow,and loves it. Sonny is talking of
taking up farming when he gets out of uniform but I am sure
that is just an idea not a reality. 
My frein[d] Marian Hall is home and I hopeto see her when I
[End Page 2]
3
get up to town.
The weather is lovely and I wish I were playing tennis and g 
golf or swimming instead of city life. I spent a week end  
with Toni but I think I wrote you about it. Hou we caught 
6 trout; broke the rod; were attacked by a swan, and then the
owner of the rod appeared in the midst of this scene and raised
hell at seeing her rod kaput. We landed the fish. It was a
good week end and I had my first game of tennis in two years.
I am so impatient to know what I am going to
do and its hell waiting and wondering and getting nowhere.
O'Conner should have written the letter to the navy but he hes
gone your way so I think its Dick Allen that has to do it,
and I dont know how strong he will put it. I just live in
hopes.
My breakfast is brought in at 8.15 every morning
whether I have gone to bed at dawn or at 10P.M. consequently
I am tired. The cloths hangers are filled with seer sucker 
suits and the bureau drawrs have nails in them. Its something!
I spent 4 hours at the office yesterday while
they figgured out how much back pay I should get. I think I
am going to get paid a per diem for all my time in Jail. Is
n't that a scream?
Do write me which way you want the wind to blow in
regard to your life so that I do not do something you dont
want.
All my love and write soon.
Gertrude Legendre
P.S. The property owner stuff does n't work as its not
pre Pearl Harbor. Maybe we could n't get back as civilians
again I dont know.
[End Page 3]
